title: ZETI Net Zero Pathway
summary: A comprehensive pathway for the global energy sector to reach net zero by 2050
overview: The ZETI Net Zero Pathway roadmap shows how the global energy sector can achieve net zero emissions by 2050. It is designed to examine what would need to happen to the energy system over the next 30 years to achieve net zero emissions by 2050. The pathway calls for rapid deployment of available technologies between now and 2030, with clean technologies in heavy industry and long-distance transport developed and brought to market in the 2030s. The pathway also requires innovation, international cooperation, and significant investment.
expertRecommendation: This scenario represents the most comprehensive global pathway to net zero and is highly recommended as a reference scenario for any climate transition assessment. It has excellent sectoral coverage and provides detailed milestones for different technologies and regions. However, analysts should note that it may be less detailed for specific regional considerations in Southeast Asia or other developing regions. Consider complementing this scenario with regional scenarios for a more complete assessment.

dataSource.description: The full scenario data is available from the ZETI website. Free summary data is available for download, while complete datasets require a ZETI data subscription.

title: FGCN Current Policies
summary: Business-as-usual baseline assuming current policies remain in place
overview: The FGCN Current Policies scenario represents a "business as usual" world where only currently implemented policies are preserved. This scenario leads to high physical risks as temperature rise is projected to reach 3째C or higher by 2100. The scenario assumes no additional policies are implemented beyond what is already in place, resulting in higher emissions throughout the projection period compared to other FGCN scenarios.
expertRecommendation: This scenario is useful as a baseline comparison to understand the implications of inaction. When conducting climate transition assessments, this scenario helps illustrate the risks of maintaining the status quo. We recommend using this alongside more ambitious scenarios to show the contrast between different policy approaches. This scenario is particularly valuable for stress testing and understanding physical climate risks.

dataSource.description: The FGCN scenario data is freely available from the FGCN website. Full datasets can be downloaded in various formats.

title: SEA Clean Energy Pathway
summary: Pathway focused on replacing coal with renewables in Southeast Asia
overview: The SEA Clean Energy Pathway scenario outlines a regionally specific pathway for Southeast Asian countries to transition away from coal-fired power generation to renewable energy sources. The scenario includes detailed projections for solar, wind, hydro, and geothermal deployment across the region, with country-specific considerations for Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam. It provides a technically feasible and economically optimal pathway that aligns with the 1.5째C global temperature goal.
expertRecommendation: This scenario is highly recommended for any assessment of power generation companies in Southeast Asia. It provides more regionally specific insights than global models and accounts for the unique characteristics of Southeast Asian power markets. The scenario is particularly useful for evaluating transition plans of coal-heavy power generators in the region. We recommend using this alongside global scenarios for a more comprehensive assessment.

dataSource.description: The full scenario data is available directly from the Southeast Energy Analysis Group website. Registration is required, but the data is free to download.

title: CoalTech CCS Transition
summary: Scenario focused on CCS deployment for existing coal infrastructure
overview: This scenario explores a transition pathway that heavily leverages carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies to reduce emissions from existing coal power plants and industrial facilities. Rather than rapid decommissioning of coal assets, this scenario models a more gradual transition where CCS is deployed at scale to allow continued operation of some coal plants while still meeting climate goals. The scenario includes detailed modeling of CCS deployment curves, costs, and infrastructure requirements.
expertRecommendation: This scenario provides a useful alternative perspective to scenarios that focus primarily on renewable deployment. It is particularly relevant for assessments of companies with younger coal assets that may be difficult to retire early, especially in regions like Southeast Asia where coal remains a significant part of the energy mix. However, we recommend using this scenario alongside others, as it relies heavily on technology deployment that has yet to be proven at scale and may overestimate the potential for CCS.

dataSource.description: The scenario data is available from the CoalTech Solutions Consortium website. Basic data is freely available, while detailed datasets require membership.

title: GreenForward EU Strategy
summary: Ambitious accelerated implementation of European Green Deal policies
overview: The GreenForward EU Strategy scenario models an ambitious implementation of European climate policies beyond the current targets. It includes accelerated phase-out of fossil fuels in power generation, rapid electrification of transport, comprehensive building renovations, and industrial decarbonization. The scenario achieves net zero emissions in the EU by 2040, a decade earlier than the current official target.
expertRecommendation: This scenario is valuable for assessing European companies and understanding the potential impacts of more ambitious EU climate policies. It presents a useful "high ambition" case for European policy evolution and is particularly relevant for financial institutions with significant European exposure. We recommend using this scenario when assessing companies with major operations in the EU, especially in sectors targeted by EU climate policies.

dataSource.description: The scenario data is publicly available through the GreenForward Policy Alliance climate modeling portal.

title: GEC SSP1-1.9
summary: Sustainable development pathway limiting warming to 1.5째C with low overshoot
overview: SSP1-1.9 is a Shared Socioeconomic Pathway that represents a sustainable development path with low challenges to mitigation and adaptation. It assumes a gradual shift away from fossil fuels, increased energy efficiency, and sustainable consumption patterns. This scenario limits global warming to 1.5째C by 2100 with limited or no overshoot, aligning with the most ambitious goal of the Paris Agreement.
expertRecommendation: This scenario is recommended as a scientific reference point for Paris-aligned transition pathways. It has comprehensive global coverage across all major sectors and is backed by the scientific authority of the GEC. However, it may lack specific regional and sectoral detail needed for company-level assessments. We recommend using this scenario to establish the scientific basis for 1.5째C alignment, complemented by more detailed sectoral or regional scenarios.

dataSource.description: The GEC SSP database is publicly available and contains the full dataset for this scenario.

title: Planned Transition Scenario
summary: Gradual, orderly transition that begins immediately and continues gradually
overview: The Planned Transition scenario assumes climate policies are introduced early and gradually become more stringent. Carbon prices increase gradually, giving companies and consumers time to adapt. Physical risks are relatively low because climate change is effectively mitigated, while transition risks are manageable due to the predictable policy environment. Global warming is limited to 2째C by the end of the century.
expertRecommendation: This scenario is valuable for understanding the financial implications of a well-managed transition. It represents a "middle ground" approach that balances climate ambition with economic realities. We recommend using this scenario for financial institutions looking to understand potential transition pathways that minimize market disruption while still achieving significant emissions reductions. The gradual nature of this scenario makes it useful for identifying near-term transition opportunities and risks.

dataSource.description: The SCTF scenario data is freely available from the SCTF website. Full datasets can be downloaded in various formats.

title: Reactive Transition Scenario
summary: Delayed transition with sudden policy changes leading to higher transition risks
overview: The Reactive Transition scenario assumes climate policies are delayed or diverge across countries and sectors. Sudden and unanticipated policies are introduced later to rapidly reduce emissions and meet climate goals. This leads to higher transition risks due to the unexpected nature of policy changes and limited time for adaptation. The scenario still limits warming to 2째C, but with higher economic costs than an orderly transition.
expertRecommendation: This scenario is particularly useful for stress testing and understanding potential financial stability implications of delayed climate action. It helps financial institutions identify potential vulnerabilities in their portfolios to sudden policy changes or technology shifts. We recommend using this scenario alongside more orderly scenarios to understand the range of potential transition pathways and associated risks. This scenario is especially relevant for financial institutions with exposure to carbon-intensive sectors that may face abrupt policy changes.

dataSource.description: The SCTF scenario data is freely available from the SCTF website. Full datasets can be downloaded in various formats.
